moves.1. c4: English opening. Here white plays as if a Sicilian with an extra tempo
moves.1... e5: Taking some of the central pie
moves.2. d3 Nf6 3. Nc3 Bb4: Black doesnt want d5 so completely owned by White.
moves.5. bxc3: white's doubled pawns are a disadvantage, yet black does little to exploit this and hey, they're both central.
moves.6. Bg5 Nc6 7. Bg2 d6 8. Nf3 Be6: ? a poor move which eventually leads to the loss of black's rook
moves.13... Rxa8 14. O-O f6: considered Bh3 yet there was not enough material to substantiate the attack
moves.15. Be3 Nc6 16. Nf3 Kf7: Black's only chance now is to keep this game closed to hinder the mobility of both of white's rooks.
moves.17. Kg2 h5 18. Nd2 Ne7 19. Nf3:
? a complete waste of a move
perhaps h4 
for the next dozen moves white habitually wastes tempos for no reason
moves.19... a5: claiming some land on the otherside of the board
moves.20... g5: ! hinder's black's dark squared bishop.  Black's pawn formation makes black's bishop a good and white's bad
moves.21. Ne4: i was half expecting Nf3 again...
moves.21... Rg8: perhaps unnecessary but black wants to be sure in case of 22 h4 gxh4 with pressure on white's g pawn and perhaps an utilisation of the bishop
moves.22. Rb2: little initiative shown from white considering the minority advance on the kingside
moves.22... h4 23. Rbb1: ? white drops more tempos than a bad conductor
moves.24. Kg1 Nf5 25. Bd2 Kg6: black slowly pushes his forces forwards, keeping the game closed to limit the effect of white's rooks
moves.32. dxc4 Nxc4 33. Bc1 Nxb2 34. Be3: ?? white losses its material advantage and now has to deal with the pawn storm on the queenside

gameName: Dropping more beats than a rapper
